page.title: 12Conservation Project-Staploe
page.content: Nationally, 5 New Agricultural Landscape experiments were designed to assess the value of concentrated farm by farm contacts, encouraging and assisting farmers to carry out wildlife and landscape conservation work. The Bedfordshire Project, including Staploe (1979-1985) covered 9 parishes. All known farmers were contacted and approximately 80% became involved in conservation work e.g. construction and cleaning ponds, laying coppicing, planting and sapling tagging in hedges, woodland and meadow management and wildflower sowing. Most of the work was in tree planting schemes, ranging from 10 trees around a farmhouse to the planting of new woods up to 5 acres. A total ot 84440 trees were planted in 260 schemes. Farmers and their staff were encouraged to carry out the work.
